comments.commentBody: I have a couple of cousins who drank Coke for breakfast as kids (in South Carolina), and struggled with their weight all their lives. The heavier one now has Alzheimer's; the other, now retired, went through yo-yo dieting and a Diet Coke habit for years. She looked great when she was slender, but it never lasted more than a few weeks. The older one was a school principal, the younger a vice president of a major retail chain--no dummies. I'm no sylph myself, and with age I've gained weight, but I've become very aware of sugar and nutrition and fake food that should be avoided. We know a lot more now than we did in the heyday of junk food.

Another thought is that without careful analysis in the literature, impression has strong headline bias and size-of-the-state-economy bias. In that case, there are two points: 1) most of the data are ignored, 2) the data that are not ignored are explained by the headline story du jour. The notion that this rationale underlies some significant portion of the data is absent from the thinking at this point.

Write the paper and help us get on the right track.

Hi MTF,

Thanks for your input.

I hear you about the vocabulary we use to describe puzzles, and there will be, in an undetermined time in the near future, a guide and glossary to help new solvers understand what we're talking about.

As for placement of the comments, that's a design issue that I don't control.

Design comment: Why are there days and days and days (and days and days and [show more] days and days) of blog content when someone just wants today's blog? Why not have a link to previous blogs so those who want to "go back" can, but everyone else doesn't have to load it all each time? Do you now how much data it costs to load all of that extra rarely-viewed material? And when the server/net is slow, it hoses half way through the load. I know  that is the new economic model for charging more for data for the telecom's (some websites get a kickback for designing this way!) but does NYT have to go along? I know the "new" convention is multiple swipes on an ipad instead of a single click to get to "more".  It's not an improvement. Flame off.
What might be helpful is to have maybe 7 days of blogs on the front page and then, just like the puzzle, have a calendar for archives.

Deb, you inquired about the new format? I think it looks like a million bucks -- or should I say 2.098 million bucks? I'm not talking DEER either. It's spiffy right down to the photo caption.

But I'm not sure a newbie would understand what is meant by "symmetrical black squares" (a square has multiple symmetries including mirror, rotational, and perhaps even radial) nor by "revealer".

I could be wrong. When I started lurking here, I allowed some time to pass between asking for definitions of terms such as "chewy", "crunchy", and "Scrabbly". (And to be honest, hundreds of crosswords later, I am still in a muddle about why it's a good thing to use "Scrabbly" letters? They have point values in Scrabble, but in books or crosswords or variety puzzles, JLO could be FLO or SLO and none would be the less for it. Not that I've noticed, anyway.)

If they're going to tinker with the blog page, how about putting a smallish jpg of the completed grid at the bottom of the page where all the empty space is? Some newbies may not like flipping back to their solution to see what the blog is talking about.

If not, the bottom part of the blog page could be used for the Comment section. The "Recommended for You" links down there are annoying.

Speaking of the completed grid, the app helpfully enters ACE in each appropriate place after the grid is filled correctly. I thought that was a nice touch -- 59% nicer than solution grids a year ago.

Wages may be growing faster than corporate profits but a couple things to consider:
Workers' wages are still dependent on what companies want to pay them, notwithstanding competition. The system has already been rigged by destroying unions, off-shoring, etc.
How do takes factor into the numbers? That's something that is subject to frequent change and could reverse any significant overall economic growth of one sector or another. (The article talks about wages, not wealth.)
What did people spend their $1900 windfall on? It's $36/week, not nothing but not much either. Where did that money go?
Is cash money substituting for other forms of compensation, like insurance or vacation?
It is a fact that the upper limit is unlimited whereas the lower limit is very limited - to zero. So you can a lot of growth at the upper margin - the rich getting richer - which pulls the average up or down without affecting the lower percentiles very much.
Maybe all these are factored into the analysis, I have no idea. But we're talking about one indicator which is only part of the picture. I hope it is in fact a trend and that normal people are better off.

Joseph, it's a fairly common thing to use a '-' that often turns out to be nonsense that allows the constructor a way out of a tight fix. That's the came today with 30/56D. However, that is not always the case. There are puzzles where the constructor uses that '-' to get you to see a pattern or think outside the box. As for ACERBITY being obscure, I'm probably the weakest solver here and I got it and thought it quite clever. As Deb is fond of saying, YMMV. Some things are in a solver's "wheelhouse," some aren't.

I'm certainly no fan of Trump as either an entertainer, businessperson, or politician (to whatever he degree he's been since announcing his run). But, he's never been a legislator, elected or otherwise. As far as we know, he's never even done any volunteer work or any sort of community service. He sure hasn't issued any policy papers, and though I haven't looked for any, I doubt he's written any substantial editorials. So, in terms of, you know, being an active member of any government, we've had an almost zero shot at hearing any coherent plans or policies. Hillary and Bernie both have substantial track records. I'm all for more actual reporting on what Trump says he'll do, how he plans to do it, and what he's done in the past that indicates any ability or lack thereof to pull off his Wonka-land.

I do wonder whether Trump's status influenced the Democratic party results in Indiana.  Certainly, a prime consideration now among remaining Democratic primary voters is, "who is most likely to defeat Donald Trump?"  Did more Indiana voters think the answer was Bernie?

It is fairly easy to see Trump's strategy. Get a bunch of one-liners and call them your policy; like, build a wall and Mexico will pay, do away with common core, bring back jobs, deport illegals, etc.  Next, be outrageous, rude, crude and unpredictable - the public will love it. Then, develop a base of uneducated people who believe whatever misfortune they experience is the government's fault. This will cause your opponent to loose it, then say, he started it. These are tactics of bullies and work well as long as you are in a crowd of friendlies. However, Trumps strength is his weakness. He got upset about small hands and he will get upset if somebody nails him on his business successes. He is banking on the fact that the Press know he is great for ratings and won't seriously confront him. You will know if you are getting to him as he will threaten to sue, we have seen it before. If we are unfortunate enough to see him elected, I am sure we will hear him say, I will fix it, but I won't tell you how - trust me, I'm smart, He will then have a surrogate implement something and if it fails, he will fire him with glee. The apprentice all over again. The bottom line is, are we prepared to have a con-artist as President or are we putting someone in office to destroy government.
